user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_cp:
```c
int32 OS_cp(const char *src, const char *dest)
{
    int32     return_code;
    int32     rd_size;
    int32     wr_size;
    int32     wr_total;
    osal_id_t file1;
    osal_id_t file2;
    uint8     copyblock[OS_CP_BLOCK_SIZE];

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(src);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(dest);

    file1       = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    file2       = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    return_code = OS_OpenCreate(&file1, src, OS_FILE_FLAG_NONE, OS_READ_ONLY);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_OpenCreate(&file2, dest, OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE | OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE, OS_WRITE_ONLY);
    }

    while (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        rd_size = OS_read(file1, copyblock, sizeof(copyblock));
        if (rd_size < 0)
        {
            return_code = rd_size;
            break;
        }
        if (rd_size == 0)
        {
            break;
        }
        wr_total = 0;
        while (wr_total < rd_size)
        {
            wr_size = OS_write(file2, &copyblock[wr_total], rd_size - wr_total);
            if (wr_size < 0)
            {
                return_code = wr_size;
                break;
            }
            wr_total += wr_size;
        }
    }

    if (OS_ObjectIdDefined(file1))
    {
        OS_close(file1);
    }
    if (OS_ObjectIdDefined(file2))
    {
        OS_close(file2);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_cp:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CP_BLOCK_SIZE 512
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint8_t   uint8
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0})
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_READ_ONLY 0
...
#define OS_WRITE_ONLY 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other constructs in the provided code are standard C language features or ordinary macro/function usages and do not, from the provided fragments, show compiler-specific language extensions. The code uses standard typedefs (from <stdint.h>), fixed-size arrays with a macro constant, ordinary control flow, and standard function/macro invocations (OS_read, OS_write, OS_OpenCreate, OS_CHECK_POINTER, etc.). No occurrences of commonly known compiler extensions are present (for example: GCC/Clang __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, zero-length arrays, or inline asm). The BUGCHECK macro is not expanded in the supplied text, so there is no visible use of an extension inside it; therefore it is not flagged here. The three fragments listed above are the only places in the provided code that may rely on a language feature that some compilers treat as nonstandard/extension, and thus should be investigated further against the target compiler documentation and language mode.
